scenario: Shares of T-Mobile (TMUS) fell 4.3% on Monday despite the Nasdaq Composite being up over 1.8%. The decline comes after two Wall Street analysts downgraded shares from a buy to a hold rating. Wells Fargo and RBC Capital lowered their price targets for TMUS to $220 and $240 respectively. The analysts cited the "low-hanging fruit" of the Sprint acquisition being behind the company and a slowdown in free cash flow growth due to a higher tax rate. TMUS trades at 11 times forward EBITDA and 15 times forward free cash flow estimates, higher than rivals Verizon and AT&T. Despite this, TMUS is still considered "best in class" and is plowing cash flow into share repurchases. The company recently raised its dividend 35% and has a 1.6% yield, with room for growth.
